solutions: Hi Dave. I'm Greg, an installation specialist, 10 year Windows MVP, and Volunteer Moderator here to help you.The two are entirely separate. This article explains the difference: https://www.digitalcitizen.life/should-you-use-...There isn't anything you can't do in Sharing with a Local Account vs. a Microsoft Account, except that the MS account is an easier way to connect to OneDrive. But you can connect to OneDrive or any other app by signing into it individually with a Local Account.At any time you can switch from a Local Account to a MS account in Settings > Accounts > Your Info > Sign in with a Microsoft Account Instead, or vice versa.There is no other default account besides the one you set up when you install Windows (always an Admin acct, btw, which is wise) or set up a new PC that comes with Windows. It can be a Local or Microsoft Account. To set up a Local Account during install or Setup after Version 1909 disconnect from the internet to force the choice. I hope this helps. solutions: Hi Nancy. I'm Greg, an installation specialist, 10 year Windows MVP, and Volunteer Moderator here to help you.Does the HDD show up in device Manager under Disk Drives at all? Instead keep your apps and programs on the Windows drive, sort your User files into their shell User folders and move those to the data drive since they suffer no speed loss from SSD>HDD while apps would.
